The kernel uses a strided memory access pattern with a stride equal to the block dimension to enable coalesced memory accesses.
The kernel avoids non-coalesced memory accesses by ensuring consecutive threads access consecutive memory locations during data loading.
The kernel performs block-level parallel reductions using shared memory and explicit synchronization (__syncthreads()).
The kernel prioritizes coalesced memory access over contiguous per-thread access patterns to improve memory throughput.
